\begin{soln}
  Clearly $f(x)$ is infinitely differentiable.
  Putting $n = 1$ in our primary equation,
  we get
  \[
    f'(x+1) = f(x+1) - f(x).
  \]
  By substituting $x \mapsto x + 1$, we get
  \[
    f'(x+2) = f(x+2) - f(x+1).
  \]
  Adding these two equations and then
  dividing by $2$ gives
  \[
    \frac{f'(x + 1) + f'(x + 2)}{2}
    = \frac{f(x + 2) - f(x)}{2}.
  \]
  Now, we put $n = 2$ in our primary equation to get
  \[
    f'(x + 2) = \frac{f(x + 2) - f(x)}{2}.
  \]
  Substituting this into our result gives
  \[
  \frac{f'(x + 1) + f'(x + 2)}{2} = f'(x + 2)
  \implies f'(x + 1) = f'(x + 2).
  \]
  Then note that $f'(x) = f'(x + 1) = \cdots = f'(x + n)$.

  To finish, note that differentiating the
  primary equation gives
  \[
    f''(x + n)
    = \frac{f'(x+n) - f'(x)}{n} = 0.
  \]
  Substituting $x \mapsto x - n$ implies $f''(x) = 0$.
  Since $f(x)$ is infinitely differentiable, $f''(x)$ is
  continuous. Integrating $f''(x) = 0$ twice gives
  $f(x) = ax + b$.

  Clearly a linear function satisfies our original
  equation and we are done.
\end{soln}
